column4: Ericsson says Swedish staff cuts running ahead of plan
column5: STOCKHOLM Struggling telecom equipment maker Ericsson  said on Thursday sweeping staff cuts in its Swedish home market were running ahead of schedule  resulting in higher restructuring costs this year.

column4: Short-seller Citron calls Express Scripts drug price culprit
column5: Short seller Citron Research's Andrew Left has turned his sights on Express Scripts Holding Co  calling the pharmacy benefit manager (PBM) the "culprit behind pharmaceutical price gouging."

column4: Lululemon quarterly sales top expectations  shares jump
column5: TORONTO Canadian yoga and leisure apparel retailer Lululemon Athletica Inc on Wednesday reported quarterly profit that beat analysts' forecasts  helped by higher-than-expected gross margins and sales.

column4: EU regulator accepts Sanofi/Regeneron's Dupixent product for review
column5: PARIS The European Medicines Agency (EMA)  the European Union's health regulator  has accepted for review the Dupixent product being developed by drugmakers Sanofi and Regeneron  the companies said on Thursday.

column4: Sears Holdings posts loss for fifth straight quarter
column5: Retailer Sears Holdings Corp reported its fifth straight quarterly loss and said there was no guarantee when it would return to profitability  underscoring its struggle to stanch a years-long decline in sales. |Â Video

column4: Abbott seeks to abort planned acquisition of Alere
column5: Abbott Laboratories  said on Wednesday that it had moved to terminate its proposed acquisition of Alere Inc   citing a "substantial loss" in the value of the diagnostics company since they struck a deal 10 months back.

column4: AT&T says vice chairman de la Vega to retire
column5: MEXICO CITY/NEW YORK AT&T Inc Vice Chairman Ralph de la Vega  who played a critical role in bringing the iPhone to the U.S. market  will retire on Dec. 31  a spokesman for the wireless carrier said on Thursday.

column4: BlackRock to move to New York's trendy Hudson Yards district
column5: NEW YORK BlackRock Inc  the world's largest asset manager  plans to move its headquarters in 2022 from midtown Manhattan to a massive new office tower in the fast-growing Hudson Yards district on the city's far West Side  the developers said on Thursday.

column4: Bristol-Myers Squibb to pay $19.5 million to settle off-label promotion case
column5: WASHINGTON Drugmaker Bristol-Myers Squibb Co will pay $19.5 million to resolve multi-state allegations that it improperly promoted a schizophrenia treatment for uses not approved by the U.S. government  New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman said on Thursday.

column4: Chevron sets 2017 capital budget  in 4th year of spending cuts
column5: Oil and gas major Chevron Corp  on Wednesday announced a $19.8 billion capital and exploratory investment program for 2017  down 42 percent from its outlays in 2015.

column4: Deutsche Bank's 'smoking gun' evidence to expand U.S. silver rigging case
column5: NEW YORK Lawyers for investors accusing several major banks of conspiring to rig silver prices are seeking to add five new defendants to the case  based what they call "smoking gun" evidence they obtained from Deutsche Bank AG following a settlement.

column4: Honda confirms new $436 million China factory amid sales surge
column5: BEIJING Honda Motor's  joint venture with Dongfeng Motor Group  will invest roughly 3 billion yuan ($436 million) in a new factory in China  the Japanese automaker said in a statement on its website on Thursday.

column4: Ex-JPMorgan employee accused of $5 million scheme to defraud bank
column5: NEW YORK A former JPMorgan Chase & Co employee who has been ordered to attend counseling for gambling is facing criminal charges that he engaged in a scheme to defraud the bank out of $5 million in order to pay personal debts.

column4: KKR wants stake in German research firm GfK to drive turnaround
column5: FRANKFURT U.S. private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts  launched a tender offer on Thursday for a stake in Germany's GfK   teaming up with the faltering market research firm to develop new computer-based strategies and fend off competition.

column4: US Steel clarifies CEO's comments on recalling jobs
column5: United States Steel Corp said on Thursday that Chief Executive Mario Longhi was referring to the whole U.S. steel industry  not US Steel  when he spoke on Wednesday about potentially restoring up to 10 000 jobs in the United States.

column4: China is still firmly on the menu for McDonald's
column5: HONG KONG China will still be on the menu for McDonald's. The $100 billion U.S. burger giant is poised to sell its outlets in mainland China and Hong Kong for up to $2 billion. Seeing this as a simple retreat from the Middle Kingdom is tempting  but wrong. As elsewhere  franchising is a better business than owning and operating stores. There are other benefits to having a Chinese partner too.

column4: Northrop names former Air Force chief of staff to board
column5: U.S. weapons maker Northrop Grumman Corp  said on Thursday it had elected General Mark Welsh  former U.S. Air Force chief of staff  to its board.

column4: Orange would consider bid for Vivendi's pay-TV if for sale - CEO
column5: SKHIRAT  Morocco France's Orange  would consider bidding for Vivendi's pay-TV Canal Plus if it came up for sale  Chief Executive Officer Stephane Richard said on Thursday.

column4: RBS ordered to hand over documents in shareholder cash call case
column5: LONDON Royal Bank of Scotland  on Thursday lost a court battle to withhold transcripts  notes and interview records from thousands of retail investors suing the bank over an ill-fated  12 billion pound ($15 billion) share sale in 2008.

column4: EU regulator accepts Sanofi/Regeneron's Dupixent product for review
column5: PARIS The European Medicines Agency (EMA)  the European Union's health regulator  has accepted for review the Dupixent product being developed by drugmakers Sanofi and Regeneron  the companies said on Thursday.

column4: Stifel  ex-executive settle SEC case over Wisconsin school investments
column5: Stifel Financial Corp's brokerage unit and an ex-executive have agreed to pay $24.6 million to resolve claims arising from the sale of risky investment products to five Wisconsin school districts ahead of the financial crisis of 2008.

column4: United Air forecasts higher Q4 profit margin due to strong bookings
column5: United Continental Holdings Inc  forecasts a higher profit margin in the fourth quarter  as bookings strengthened and expenses related to employment benefits were lower than expected  the company said on Thursday.

column4: US Steel clarifies CEO's comments on recalling jobs
column5: United States Steel Corp said on Thursday that Chief Executive Mario Longhi was referring to the whole U.S. steel industry  not US Steel  when he spoke on Wednesday about potentially restoring up to 10 000 jobs in the United States.

column4: Wells Fargo picks four directors for sales scandal probe: source
column5: Wells Fargo & Co  Chairman Stephen Sanger and Vice Chair Elizabeth Duke have been named to a four-member committee that will lead an internal investigation into the bank's recent sales scandal  a person familiar with the matter said on Thursday.
